subject: Re: [junit] Re: Anyone use JUnit with Ant and Apache Digester?
msgSnippet: Hi I am using junit with Ant and Weblogic.Any queries please let me know, Thanks Praveen paolovalladolid  wrote: Not really. I had
messageBody:
Hi
I am using junit with Ant and Weblogic.Any queries please let me know,

Thanks
Praveen

paolovalladolid <paolovalladolid@...> wrote:
Not really.

I had originally worked under the assumption that my Java application
would be invoked with the XML file dropped (by an _external_ process)
into my classpath. As previously described, the 5 or so variations of
calls to getResource()/getResourceAsStream() that I tried worked great
when the application was invoked by calling the application's main()
method directly, but did not work at all when called by JUnit's
TestRunner.

I understand the disadvantages of using a File object vs. using
getResourceXXX(). But as I mentioned previously, the XML data file is
going to be dropped at some predetermined C:\ folder, without any
guarantee as to where my application will be installed, as it is going
to be integrated into a larger, multi-application process.

Thanks for the informative article, however.

Paolo


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, jc <john.cavacas@g...> wrote:
> Well, that may explain your problems. When using getResource() or
> getResourceAsStream() you have to be conserned about where you are
> calling that code from. Have a look at this old JavaWorld article, it
> explains the issues well:
>
>
http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/javaqa/2003-08/01-qa-0808-property.html
>
> /jc
>
>
>
> On 4/29/05, paolovalladolid <paolovalladolid@y...> wrote:
> > As it turns out I now have no choice but to use the method of creating
> > a File object from my "loadFile" String and calling
> > myDigester.parse(fileObj) on it, because the file is to be loaded by
> > an external process into another folder that is not guaranteed to be
> > in the classpath.
> >
> > I had loadFile = "mydata.xml" when I was trying to parse it from my
> > classpath with getResource()/getResourceAsStream().
> >
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, jc <john.cavacas@g...> wrote:
> > > Nah don't do that :)
> > >
> > > What is the value of "loadFile" when running under Junit and when
> > > running from the command line?
> > >
> > > I've never had a problem loading files from the classpath with
Junit.
> > >
> > > On 4/27/05, paolovalladolid <paolovalladolid@y...> wrote:
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > "loadFile" is a String holding the name of the XML file to be
parsed
> > > > by Digester. My Ant script copies it into the classes folder.
> > > >
> > > > MyClass has its own main() method. When I invoke MyClass via
a call
> > > > from the command line (embedded in a Windows bat file),
MyClass find
> > > > the file just fine. When MyClass is invoked by TestMyClass
(running
> > > > under JUnit), it cannot find the XML file.
> > > >
> > > > In my searches of this group archive and the Web, I have seen
> > > > references to JUnit's custom ClassLoader and how it has trouble
> > > > finding files in the classpath, but no solutions/workarounds.
> > > >
> > > > I guess for now I can try reading files via streams from File
objects
> > > > instead of using getResource() or getResourceAsStream().
> > > >
> > > > Paolo
> > > >
> > > > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, jc <john.cavacas@g...> wrote:
> > > > > What is the value of "loadFile"? Is "loadFile" in your
classpath?
> > > > >
> > > > > jc
> > > > >
> > > > > On 4/26/05, paolovalladolid <paolovalladolid@y...> wrote:
> > > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > > > > So far I have tried the following variations:
> > > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > >
> >
Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader().getResourceAsStream(loadFile);
> > > > > >
> > > > > > TestMyJUnitTest.class.getResourceAsStream(loadFile);
> > > > > >
> > > > > > this.getClass().getResourceAsStream(loadFile);
> > > > > >
> > > > > > MyClass.class.getResourceAsStream(loadFile);
> > > > > >
> > > > > > getClass().getClassLoader().getResourceAsStream(loadFile);
> > > > > >
> > > > > > None of these produce a non-null InputStream object for the
> > Digester
> > > > > > to work with. I have verified that Ant properly copies all
> > the XML
> > > > > > files I want Digester to parse into my classes.ant tree.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > What else do I need to look at?
> > > > > >
> > > > > >
